text: VIDEO FOOTAGE -— Open in a dark hallway. Someone off-camera fusses with th video settings as they walk down a corridor towards a fam gathering. At the center of everyone’s attention we find a girl at f years old. She wears a set of cowboy boots and a red cowb hat. She stretches, practices aerobics. Her hair is tease and wild. Another young girl who looks nearly identical sits off to side. Despite the verbose nature of the text, a NARRATOR speaks over the image in an unaffected tone.

Celeste was born in America in 1986. Considering her parent’s background, education, and socioeconomic status - being on the losing side of “Reaganomics” - the name of Latin origin seemed an especially poetic choice. It carved her out some pre-determined destination; a route which to travel by. She performs a sort of clumsy square dance in front of wh her grandfather and uncle play a duet and sing at a Casio keyboard.
Celeste, look at me. Look at the camera. She ignores the request.

-and many years before CE-LE-STE rolled off the cultural tongue like a principled anecdote one senses they were born knowing; she might not have been described as all that special or conspicuously talented, however, she did possess that proverbial “something” which on occasion captured the attention of her teachers and young peers.  3. A few other family members cheer her on, laughing and gay but CELESTE is lost, staring at her feet trying not to tr in her stiff new boots.
Darling, look at me. Look up.

Despite what naysayers or haters later perceived of her ingenuity, she was actually a very savvy businesswoman. In the beginning, she was kind and full of grace, and at least she wrote her own lyrics; no one could take that away from her. The YOUNG GIRL finally acknowledge’s the OFF-CAMERA VOICE Her eyes are blue and piercing. Her expression is possess
Can you sing us the song you sang to me in the car? She doesn’t reply but her gaze remains locked on the lens

A booming orchestral score chugs, building towards a gran swooning movement... BLACK fades and gives way to a rush of color, shades of violet and cyan. The NARRATOR’s voice now fights to be heard over the increasingly cacophonous sound. The shape of the recordin evolves into something like a bad radio transmission.
She would be 13 going on 14 years old in the year 2000, the dawn of the new millennium.
Finally, the symphony begins to mimic the simpler chord progressions of a contemporary pop song.
Pop music overtakes the soundtrack.
WIDE ON -— A music video glows off a television box hinged to the ceiling. An empty treadmill is on at full-speed.

WIDE ON -— A row of middle-class residences line a quiet neighborhoo street. The mood is relentlessly sombre. An ominous dark blue hue tints at dusk.  5. A few street lamps turn on with their timers and light po out living room windows from the television sets nestled inside.
Street lamps buzz and after some time turn on in staggere sets illuminating the mall lot. A few kids hang out smoki by the entrance
One of the restaurant’s rotating signs.
Two different food chains compete for attention situated across from one another. A black SUV pulls away from the drive-thru.
The SUV speeds fast across the landscape, a bad omen. It’s darker out with every new angle.

A high school campus at night. Heaps of kids step out of their parents’ cars. There’s an event on. The SUV enters frame and the composition adjusts slightly the left compensating for the vehicle’s movement. The distance, the quality of light - it’s sci-fi.

It’s New Year’s eve.  LONG LENS ON -— The camera meticulously pans the room. A middle school cafeteria’s been set up as a makeshift dance hall. Teens dance a bit provocatively with one another. A few grind up and down each other’s thighs. They are having a great time. The energy is infectious, intoxicating. After some time, a fight seems to break out for no appare reason. The music is too loud to make out anything specif of the conflict. An adult supervisor, MS. DWYER, steps in to break up the fight. One YOUNG MAN is left in tears. He seems deeply ashamed. MS. DWYER leans to him, putting an affectionate hand on h shoulder. The kid brushes it off and we pan with him as h exits by himself.
The YOUNG MAN steps out and walks across the lot.

We track with the boy for an extended period of time. He quivers and heaves deep visible breaths into the cold nig air. He hums a tune. After a while some light orchestra joins but before it can develop into much of anything, a hard c to-
The students chant!
Before the midnight kiss --
MEDIUM ON — MS. DWYER stands near the front door of her classroom welcoming students.
Good morning, Ms. Dwyer.
Welcome back. How was break?
Fine, thanks. Kids file in pulling off winter jackets and taking their seats off-screen. CELESTE walks by unnoticed. Another student, THERESE, stops to chat with MS. DWYER.
Morning. SFX: The bell rings.
Happy New Year. Did you change your hair, Therese?
My sister cut it. She’s a hairdresser.
Does she work in town? I’ve been wanting a cut like that.
(flattered) Really? She lives out of state. She was visiting us for the holidays but I can let you know when she’s back.
Would you mind?
Sure, I can. MS. DWYER walks over to her desk and sorts through a few papers.
(enthusiastic) Welcome back, everyone. Did you have a good break? A few reply “yes.”
I got some news yesterday about our computer appeal.
What is it? MS. DWYER regards her watch.
I want to wait and share once everyone is here. We are just waiting on Adam and Elyse.
Probably be awhile.
Why? EVAN murmurs something to the kid next to him.
Evan, whatever you’re saying to him, save it for after class. Let’s please not start the year at odds. THERESE speaks up.
I saw Adam 15 minutes ago.
Okay, then we'll wait.
Are they giving us desktops?
I said we'll wait -- The YOUNG MAN from the school dance opens the door interrupting the flow of conversation. MS. DWYER turns to address him...
Excuse me.
Yes? He asserts himself.
My name is Cullen Active.
What?
My name is Cullen Active.

Yes, Cullen, I know. The YOUNG MAN nimbly moves a handgun from the inner part his jacket and shoots MS. DWYER in the stomach in a singl shot. The class shrieks and rush in a panic towards the back of class. One girl sits frozen in her seat.
A light smatter of blood adorns CELESTE’s face. Her mouth slacks agape.
Celeste? Extended beat. YOUNG MAN (CONT’D) Celeste, go stand with the others. CELESTE doesn’t move a muscle. YOUNG MAN (CONT’D) Please, Celeste. She blinks.
Is she breathing-
(deliberate) No. (MORE )
Celeste, I need you to step away from the windows because in a few minutes there will be an explosion. There’s an audible gasp from the other students. One girl begs off-camera.
(completely distressed) What are you doing?! (beat) Why are you doing this?

CULLEN, the YOUNG MAN, steps further inside revealing a machine gun. Everyone screams. CULLEN struggles lifting the heavy firearm but after a fe moments manages to fire it off at the ceiling. Debris fal into the room.
Stop!

Please. Please stop. I am standing, I’1l stand. CELESTE stands and camera booms up with her, accommodatin her movement. Focus is shallow as she decides to turn her back on CULLE and approach the group. Finally she reaches the others an turns around.
Kids flood the hallways in terror. Adults hover over them trying their best to coordinate a safe exit.
Several kids hang from the second story of the school lowering themselves to safety.
From a distance, among the foothills, the campus is After some time, a car explodes in the parking lot.
CELESTE’s expression falls between a state of shock grace... MS. DWYER’s class is evermore hysterical.
Cullen. CULLEN sounds as if he might be crying now.
Cullen, please let us go.
I killed plenty of people. I can’t now.
Please. CELESTE blinks a tear.
Please at least let everyone else out of here and I'll stay here with you.
What are we going to do? A moment passes before some words fall from Celeste’ mouth...
We'll pray together. She turns to comfort the girl next to her.

Shh... It’s going to be okay,-- 11. peaceful. and s  12. A round of shots light up the screen and CELESTE is shot through the side of her neck. She drops out of frame with all of her weight in a loud thud.
Officers cautiously file in according to a well-coordinat protocol.
Clear.

STEADICAM ON — A SWAT team who seem to have entered the building from another entrance make their way down the corridor. SFX: We hear each voice as if over a police radio. It’s disorienting and does not always correspond with the imag there are additional officers coming over the feed. They splinter off and check room after room for survivors The sequence is relentless, unsettling, redundant.
Clear. They push down further.
Clear. A new voice interjects over the radio.

Request for immediate medical assistance. We have seven kids here, four in critical condition, not responding, three dead in the south-facing corridor’s girl’s bathroom, Ist floor. Further, into the next room.
Clear. Further again, into the next room.  13.
Clear on the left. SWAT 1 enters the next door.
Christ. I have three bodies, fatally-wounded, adults, 1 female, 2 male, room 111.
We'll come back. Keep pushing.

Shooter and hostages are last reported in the wing overhead... Stairs are coming up on the right. We follow the team to the right and all the way up the stairs. On the second floor now, the team checks room 211.
Clear. They move on to room 212 and open the door.

(voice cracks in agony) Oh no. Oh, no no no no. MS. DWYER’s class appears dead. They lie piled on top of each other in the back of the class. CULLEN is also dead where he previously stood. There’s bl absolutely everywhere. Several students moan at the sound of the SWAT team. Seve members of the team rush to their aid.
(to the students) We're going to get you out of here. We're here to help. SWAT 2 speaks into his radio.
Room 212, second floor, east-facing corridor, suspect is deceased. Several hostages are still alive, critically injured.  14.

SFX: Berlioz’s choral piece “La Damnation de Faust” rings out... The rich orchestral score swells over the view of the sch from a helicopter. Bold FRONT CREDITS in primary hues roll up over the image a scroll.
CREDITS SCROLL continues over the following...
CELESTE is partially wrapped in foil, upside down on the gurney. An oxygen mask covers her face. The scene is frantic. Paramedics hover over her body.

Celeste, you’re doing so good. You just keep breathing, honey. You're gonna feel a pinch at the base of your spine. The piece of music Cullen hummed as he walked home alone before reprises over a NEW ANGLE ON CELESTE.
She seems to hum along underneath the mask.

AN EXTENDED SERIES OF VERITE STYLE CLOSE-UPS -— Victims of the massacre exercise in pained, deliberate movements. A few weeks have passed. Some victims seem more adapted to their new circumstances than others. ANGLE ON -— CELESTE’s neck is heavily bandaged. She slowly limps acro the space with her MOTHER and PHYSICAL THERAPIST at her s CELESTE’S MOTHER looks like she hasn’t slept in weeks. CELESTE suddenly stops.  CELESTE’s 15. CELESTE’S MOTHER Tell us if you’re going to be sick again.
I'm sorry... CELESTE’S MOTHER Don’t be sorry.
I’ve seen much worse. What are you feeling now?
I feel like I’m on a boat.
Nausea won't subside?
It’s not just that. I just feel like I’m spinning. You think it’s in my head?
I don’t think it’s in your head at all. I just don’t think this has to do with the spinal injury. Are your ears ringing?
I need to sit. CELESTE’S MOTHER I‘1l get your chair. MOTHER leaves CELESTE who breathes hard.
Take another step with me while we wait for your mom. CELESTE takes another pained step. Moments later she returns with a wheelchair. CELESTE’S MOTHER Sit, my love. CELESTE sits sluggishly.  16.
Where’s dad and Eleanor? CELESTE’S MOTHER They went to get us some food.
Some of the other kids have complained about ringing in their ears from the gun blasts. I/’11 talk to your doctor.
CELESTE’s body glides into a CAT scan. Her skin appears translucent underneath the violet lamp. Here, she looks l a cyborg.

CELESTE’s older sister, ELEANOR (16), lies entangled in CELESTE’s embrace. She cries for a long time holding onto her sister tight. The image is a kind of modern chiaroscuro; so dark that i resembles something like a Bill Henson photograph.

I’m so sorry I was sick. I should have been there for you. I’m so grateful you're alive. I think I would have died - or just killed myself. I don’t think I could have standed it. I’m here now and I am never going to leave you - ever. CELESTE cries now too, smiles, and then breaks into a fit laughter.
Oh, God, Ellie. I think I've done something terrible. ELEANOR’s face wrinkles in anguish.
It’s not your fault. What more could you have done? You’re safe with me.  17.
CELESTE lies in bed with a travel CASIO keyboard on her l She plays with various settings and sound FX - future sou rainforest reverb.

ELEANOR reads a magazine at the end of the hospital bed. FATHER reads a book in a chair. Magazine clippings are ta all around CELESTE’S bed. Take-out containers and fast fo bags additionally litter the scene. A nurse enters...
Some news people are here and are requesting an interview. CELESTE’S FATHER Don’t look at me. It’s up to her. CELESTE stops playing her keyboard...
I don’t want anyone to see me like this.
You look fine. CELESTE looks at ELEANOR...
Can you talk to them?
Me? What am I supposed to say? I wasn’t there.
Just tell them how sorry we are for everyone that died. ELEANOR looks at their dad. CELESTE’S FATHER (shrugs ) Call mom.
Are you sure, Celeste? CELESTE nods...  18.
I can take you to a telephone. ELEANOR gets off the bed and exits the room with the NURS CELESTE looks at her FATHER.

I think I want to try and sleep for awhile. He immediately stands, taking the hint. CELESTE’S FATHER Yeah, I was going to try and take your mom out and get her mind off things... You need anything more than the piano? I got a guitar in the basement. I can teach you to play it.
Thanks but it’s hard for me to tilt my head down. CELESTE’S FATHER All right, I‘'1l see you in the morning. I love you to the moon and back.
I know. Me too. Please don’t be sad. CELESTE’S FATHER I’m not sad. I’m relieved.
ELEANOR lies with her head on CELESTE who plays a melody her keyboard. Celeste seems to have something in mind but struggles to find the right note. They begin to hum...

head_text.subj: SLOW FRONTAL PUSH IN ON CELESTE -

text: The light from the hospital television set illuminates th darkness of her concerned expression. For a flash, she suddenly appears quite iconic.  19.
One hundred persons walk in silence carrying candles bene their chins.

Two sophomore students, Vanessa Cooke and Elyse Hanlin, remain in eritical condition. Hold them especially in your prayers and please join me in a moment of silence. ANGLE ON -— CELESTE’s MOTHER and FATHER who push CELESTE in a wheelch ELEANOR walks to the side.
FATHER CLIFF preaches in front of his congregation. He st to cry occasionally without affectation. His tone is dire and sincere. He breathes evenly trying to gather himself.

You'll have to excuse me. These are not only tears of profound sorrow but of profound joy, as well, because I see so many young faces here before me whom we helplessly feared for many hours forever lost. The audience is audibly moved by his frankness.

We are here to honor your heroism and mourn the loss of your loved ones and peers. First, I have a difficult request to put forth but as I see it, it’s the only way we might begin to move forward... Heaving sobs ring out off-screen.  20.

Ferocious anger and hatred caused this and we can’t have any more anger around us this minute so I must ask you to include the perpetrator of these vicious attacks and his parents in our prayers tonight, as they too lost their child in January. ANGLE ON -— Photographers stand at the side aisles. Bulbs flash again and again.

By this way of healing prayer, victims of the tragedy will be released from their own grief and rage in the afterlife, and they shall live forever in our hearts. Lives lost too young here on earth but with whom we all anxiously wait to be reunited. They walk with God now...

VARIOUS PARISHIONERS weep... The crowd largely dons their school colors and team jerseys. ANGLE ON -— We finally reach ELEANOR and CELESTE who sit quietly like couple of nuns with their eyes reverently closed.

We'll be inviting Ridgewood students to take my place - share their thoughts, memories, feelings with all of you. To begin, please join me in welcoming a very brave young woman to the piano. She has prepared a piece of music for us all tonight. Celeste? CELESTE uses a set of crutches to get herself to a piano that’s been set up with a microphone. She slides onto the bench and clears her throat... She really looks very beautiful. A necklace covers her bandaged neck. Everyone claps for her in support.

(into the mic) Uh, I tried to prepare something to say but I couldn’t really put my feelings into words exactly so I thought I’d try and do this instead. My sister, Ellie, helped me. She starts meekly but after the first verse, her voice be to rise up emotively.

(sings) Don’t be afraid father, you raised us well. I heard your voice cry out with the day’s first bell. And the bells tolled and the sirens rang o-ut I can feel my chest tightening, squeezing on-to my he-art The music moves through her. Whatever of it’s clumsiness, the performance is undeniably moving.
(shouts, sings) So, if fear is like fire then I’m burning AND if it’s fear you desire to locate in me, then I’m turning right back around and RUNNING INTO
So now I’m asking you, am I allowed to ever sleep again? Am I allowed to ever dream again? How may I care-less-ly ever live care-free again?
A news crew adjusts their lens for a close-up.
At the advice of her first ever producer, Celeste would change the lyric from “I” to “we,” and shortly thereafter, the entire country fell into step with her sentiment. (MORE )

It was not her grief anymore, it was their grief; no longer merely her experience, they reclaimed it as their own. We push towards them, they push towards us. NARRATOR (CONT’D) The song would become an anthem for the nation. Simply put, it was a hit.

A SERIES OF BOLD, ICONIC SHOTS OF THE CITY. The score swe and pulses. LONG LENS ON -— Bright-eyed CELESTE is walking again. She and ELEANOR traverse the avenue next to an unkempt rock and roll MANA Focus favors CELESTE as they walk amongst pedestrians. Sh looks like a star.
CELESTE stands in the mic room next to a SESSION BASSIST.

(sings) Don’t be afraid father, you raised us well. I heard your voice cry out with the day’s first bell. And the bells tolled and the sirens rang o-ut I can feel my chest tightening, squeezing on-to my he-art CELESTE stops and swallows.
Sorry. I’m getting thrown off from hearing my own voice. ANGLE ON -— MUSIC PRODUCER in the control room.  23.
You want me to pull that out?
If you can do that, thanks.
(mutters ) No problem.
CELESTE & the SESSION BASSIST
You like when I come down to a G for the refrain?
No, not that. I thought that was D, sorry.
That is the D, just next to it.
Oh! Then yes, I like the G.
A team of Scandinavian producers, ELEANOR, several Heads Department, and CELESTE’s new MANAGER stand at the contro board. THE MANAGER hits a button so she can hear him.
you wanna step out for a moment, get some fresh air?
THE MANAGER paces around CELESTE with ferocious, anxious energy. He stammers, stutters, hammers through the language...
you okay in there, you in over your head?  24.
No, I’m good.

remember what I told you at your parent’s place, the first time i saw you? CELESTE blinks, not sure where he’s going with this. THE MANAGER (CONT’D) you just gotta shut your eyes and pretend like you’re in your bedroom. you're just dancing in your bedroom and no one is looking at you. you don’t have a care in the world
Yeah.

(smiles) you gotta tell me if i’m not making sense, okay? you got your head on so straight that half the time i forget you’re a kid. it’s okay if you don’t understand something and you need me to explain, okay?
That’s okay.

you gotta tune all these people out and just sing from your gut cause i know you’re trying to help out in there but we only got 45 minutes left or this all gets very expensive. don’t worry yourself too much with the technical stuff anyway because I’1l tell you, those people in there aren’t coming to listen to that fuckin’ bass player riff like he’s Jaco Pastorius. this is your show. remember that and run it, okay? CELESTE blinks.
Okay.  25.
you ready to head back in?
Yes, but can you do me a favor?
anything.
Can you watch your language around, Eleanor? It really bothers her when people swear.
yeah, i’m sorry. i wasn’t thinking. i didn’t mean to swear at you. forgive me.
CELESTE’s crown her face who stands at the mic. A pair of headphones head.

I’ve just cut together something for the first and last verse and it actually seems like it’s working really well. We might be over- thinking it. In the bridge though, there’s a little crack or hiccup or something on the delivery of “So now I’m asking...” so maybe let’s just take it from there? CELESTE has assumed a new confidence. ANGLE ON -—
Great. I’1l nail it and then can we get started on Please Remember?
Sorry but which section is that?
It’s the next track. The MUSIC PRODUCER behind the glass.  26.
Ah! Yes. Let’s get a head start on tomorrow.
The girls sit reading a magazine next to THE MANAGER.
Camera pans with a young woman, MARKETING PR, as she ente and sits at a dark conference table across CELESTE, ELEAN and THE MANAGER.
Sorry, I’m late. Thanks for waiting. THE MANAGER nods.
(to CELESTE and ELEANOR) Have you girls been enjoying your stay?
Yes, the hotel’s very nice. CELESTE is focused, intuitively professional somehow.
Yes, it’s great. So, what’s next?
she beat me to the punch. MARKETING PR clears her throat.
Well, a few things. First, I’ve been meaning to ask you if you have any background in dance or if your injury prevents you from...
I used to take ballet. BEAT.
And no, I just have to be careful.  27.
That’s great. Internally, we've been discussing a few upcoming appearances we’d like to pitch you for and we’d love to set you up with a choreographer.
Okay. What kind of appearances?

In-store performances, things like that. It’s a great way to introduce your live experience to the public and a great way for you to get your feet wet, in turn. Beat. Something heavy hangs in the air.
Celeste, we really love what you do here-
Thanks.
-but after everything you've been through, I just think it’s necessary to be straight with you and let you know that there’s no guarantee these new tracks will work-
hey, hey, hey, she’s 14 years old. you don’t need to talk that way to the kid. talk to me that way, not her. MARKETING PR is very firm with THE MANAGER.

Let me finish please. (back to Celeste) Before we go ahead making a lot of plans together, it would be unconscionable for me to not make a young person like yourself fully cognizant of the reality of the situation. You’ve given us a great demo to work with and we are going to pitch it hard but the rest is out of our hands.  28.
It’s fine. If it works, great, if not, that’s okay too. MARKETING PR smiles. She removes some mock-ups from a fil
Onto the fun stuff then, this is what we had in mind in terms of artwork for the EP we’ll be sending to the stations. What do you think?
Yeah, it’s good, I like it. THE MANAGER is unimpressed, a bit like a petulant kid.
less beige.
We can change the color. Right now, try and focus more on the feeling of the layout. CELESTE looks at him.
I like it.
I like it too.
great, they know what they like.

(simple) That's great, we love it. The lyric inside of the font gives it precedence - the sentient of a new voice being announced - but the most important thing to us is that you feel well-represented.
I feel well-represented.
We urgently follow THE MANAGER, CELESTE, and ELEANOR.

as your representative, i’d like to express how highly unusual and inappropriate that woman’s conduct was. i had no idea she was going to sit down and give you a list of reasons she’s not to be held accountable if she fails at her job. these sales people; five minutes into a meeting you know they couldn’t sell a life-jacket to natalie wood.
She was just telling me not to get my hopes up.
of course you should get your hopes up.
CELESTE walks on a treadmill. After some time, she begins to adjust the settings to something more challenging. She sets her pace to a jog. Her breathing rises in intensity.
Quiet... The light is beautiful in the studio. Particle M falls around.
CELESTE and a CHOREOGRAPHER work on a series of moves for upcoming performances.

Keep your abdominal muscles as stiff as you can. She does as she’s asked, leaps into his arms. She bites h lip.  30. CHOREOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Okay, almost, and again. She repeats the steps and leaps into his arms. CHOREOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Better. Try again. The CHOREOGRAPHER puts her down. She winces in pain. CHOREOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Are you all right? We can take a break.
I’m fine, but can we turn the music on?
Yeah, let me put the disc on. The choreographer steps over to a CD player as CELESTE wa around for a moment trying to shake the pain off. CHOREOGRAPHER (CONT’D) You ready?

Yes, I’m ready The CHOREOGRAPHER presses play... SFX: A NEW SONG OF CELESTE’S BLARES LOUD IN THE STUDIO SP ALREADY FROM THE FIRST FEW BARS, IT’S EXTREMELY EFFECTIVE CATCHY. CELESTE and her CHOREOGRAPHER begin again working on a se of steps. She’s doing quite well.

Good! She looks at him and takes a few more impressive steps. CHOREOGRAPHER (CONT’D) That’s great. Hold on.. He runs over and stops the disc, restarts.  31. CHOREOGRAPHER (CONT’D) (shouts over music) Let’s do it again but this time try and sing a little as we go and see how it feels. Focus on your breathing, otherwise, you won't have enough air to get through the track. She retraces the same steps and sings.

(sings along with the recording of her own voice) Remember how things used to be?! How good it felt in the back of your car with your arms aro-und me? Remember when you used to you loved me? Well, you can forget all that now because I’m moving to the big ci-ty.
Use your body to give your voice emphasis when it needs it! She takes four steps, turns.
(sings) Remember! When you used to have me? Well, hold on tight to that baby cause now it’s just a memory.
CELESTE and ELEANOR do their make up in the mirror. They straight out of a William Eggleston picture.
Did you call mom?
Yeah. I told her you were busy.
How’d she sound?  32.
I don’t know. Kind of sad. She misses us.
We are going to be home so soon though.
What if you get really big?
First of all, I don’t think that’s even happening and second, even if it did, it’s not like I wouldn’t come back home all the time. CELESTE turns to look at ELEANOR.
Are you sure I’m gonna be able to get in anywhere? CELESTE keeps her face straight trying to present her “ne look” to ELEANOR.
Totally. You look like you're 22.
No way.
You do. ELEANOR does a playful voice.
“Excuse me, sir, have you met my baby sister? She’s so sexy isn’t she?”
Shut up.
It’s true. SFX: A knock comes at the front door. CELESTE exits.  33.
CELESTE enters frame and cracks open the door...
i got a call from that- He whispers the next word. THE MANAGER (CONT’D) (whispers) -bitch- He continues in a normal voice. THE MANAGER (CONT’D) -we met with that you’1l want to know about.
Is it bad?
are you gonna let me in?
Ellie’s getting dressed. THE MANAGER stays in the doorframe.
they shopped it around to radio-
And what?!
(calm, collected) -and we did it. Please Remember is testing in the mid-nineties.
What about the other ones? THE MANAGER furrows his brow.
they did fine i think but we only needed one to work. Beat. THE MANAGER (CONT’D) you don’t seem very excited.  34.
I am, I’m just overwhelmed, I guess.
A & Ris gonna send through a list of their acts they think you can open for in the spring.
I can’t believe this. Oh my god.
listen, i’m gonna send you home for a week or two and i want you to rest up cause guess what? i’m taking you to stockholm after the break.
What?!

they want enough tracks for an album and i want you working with this guy. the best. you’d know his stuff if you knew he wrote it. he’s written everything - hits - andi told him to make space for you. he said okay if we come to him.
In Sweden?
whatever you got that’s half- written, ideas, whatever you got. let's go lay it down. ELEANOR steps out of the bathroom, having washed all her up off.
See, I told you you would get really big. ELEANOR smiles a half moon.

CELESTE AND ELEANOR’S TRIP TO SWEDEN SET TO THE SCANDINAVIAN CHILDREN’S SONG, “DYRENE I AFRIKA.” - The girls systematically test perfumes next to THE MANA at duty free in an airport. - Various shots of rain on the European motorway. - Eleanor and Celeste sleep inside the van.

It’s not for public use or anything. Just for me. It will only take a minute. CELESTE finally looks up at him defiantly revealing the smeared make-up from her tears.
Is this really what you want a picture with? I’m trying to talk with my daughter.
I’m sorry but you really don’t have to use that tone with me. I think I asked you very nicely.
Let’s just go. Without warning, CELESTE suddenly slams her hands on the table.
Alright, m’am. I was trying to be friendly with you but now I’m going to have to ask you to leave the restaurant.
Are you fucking serious, man?
Please don’t use that language with me.  69. CELESTE stands and gets in his face.
How dare you, motherfucker. The RESTAURANT MANAGER calls over to the SERVER.
Ally, can you call the cops please.
Who the fuck do you think you are.
I was about to ask you the same thing. I can smell that you have alcohol on your breath, miss, so I won't take this personally.
Are you trying to embarrass me in front of my daughter.
I didn’t even know you had a daughter. I just came over to be friendly and then you started shouting at me and now I’m telling you to leave my restaurant or I’m calling the cops.
Please, let’s go! CELESTE considers her options and then turns exits the restaurant with ALBERTINE.
(on the way out) You should be ashamed of yourself, prick. The door shuts.
No, you should be ashamed, miss. The RESTAURANT MANAGER turns to his staff members. RESTAURANT MANAGER (CONT’D) Can you believe that crazy bitch? Mike, did you get that on camera?  70.

SFX: Richard Wagner’s Rienzi Cverture underscores the sce It violently fights the wind, conversation, and traffic outside. STEADICAM ON — We follow CELESTE who has her arms wrapped ALBERTINE’s shoulders.
Let’s make a right here and go around the back so we don’t have to deal with all those shitheads out front. They turn right and walk... Beat.
I’m really sorry I lost my cool with that guy.
He was asking for it but I don’t want to talk about it.
You seem shook up. That kind of thing doesn’t happen all the time, you know, but sometimes it does and I gotta protect myself.
I said I don’t want to talk about it.
But baby, we gotta talk about it, otherwise, it’s just gonna hang in the air. Why don’t you want to talk to me? ALBERTINE sulks.
You got tears in your eyes. Come on, what is it? ALBERTINE’s voice cracks with heartbreak but they never s walking.
(shattered) I’m worried about you!
Worried about me?! Come on, you don’t need to worry about ME. I’m solid. I worry about YOU. That’s my job, to worry about you. shakes her head.
You’re skinnier than I am.
That’s cause I’m in great shape from going out and dancing my ass off every night. CELESTE squeezes her close. ALBERTINE wipes some tears of her face.

Come on, baby. You’re breaking my heart. Listen up, what that guy said about me having alcohol on my breath; that was a terrible thing to imply in front of you and instead of just ignoring the elephant in the room, we need to talk about it, head-on. CELESTE finds the words...

I ordered a glass of wine from them in a plastic cup cause I needed to let go of some tension I’m having about tonight and I didn’t want you to think there was anything to worry about. I swear on your life I wasn’t drinking before that today. You don’t need to worry about stuff like that, okay? The girls continue their walk and talk down the boulevard diegetic sound fades out and the NARRATOR takes over.  72.

In 2011, Celeste had drunk herself blind, or more precisely, blind in one eye, but had waited to tell a physician about the trouble she’d been having, too embarrassed to explain that while touring the less inhabited, and therefore less inhibited, parts of the southern United States, she had managed to damage the optic nerve in her left eye by ingesting various forms of methanol during a stint of binge drinking household cleaning products across three state lines. Shortly thereafter, when back at home, she found herself at the center of a very public dispute over a traffic collision and one pedestrian’s crushed left leg and pelvis. The girls continue to walk and comfort each other. NARRATOR (CONT’D) The victim of this short-lived episode in her life saw an opportunity and seized it. That golden ticket came in the form of a nearly seventeen million dollar settlement which was to remain for all intents and purposes, under the table. All just another flame in the crowd of what Celeste perceived a decade-long witch hunt. Whatever it was, Celeste needed something big to pull her out of this mess, a show that could put Ellie, Albertine, and herself back on track. ALBERTINE looks like she’s starting to let CELESTE cheer up. Diegtic sound resumes for a moment...
What is it? You got something else on your mind?
It’s nothing.  73.
Stop it. What is it? Diegtic sound fades out and the narrator resumes...

Albertine had lost her virginity the weekend prior to leaving for this first unveiling of Celeste’s 6th studio recording, Vox Lux, in Atlantic City, and yearned to share the galvanizing details with her mother. She had made herself sick with anticipation every day since and looked forward to the initial shock or sense of failure it might inspire in Celeste whom, albeit, no stranger to crimes of passion in her youth, had always spoken severely of young men; even warning of them more than mixing uppers with downers, for example. The girls turn a corner into the backlot of the hotel whe security stands already anticipating CELESTE’s re-entranc NARRATOR (CONT’D) If all went according to plan, the news might just strike up a long- misplaced maternal instinct and Celeste would be forced to act as her confidant.
ELEANOR answers the door to CELESTE.
That was a fast- ELEANOR sees that ALBERTINE isn’t with CELESTE.
Where’s Albertine? CELESTE pushes past ELEANOR into the room. INT. ELEANOR’S HOTEL ROOM - LATER CELESTE paces circles around ELEANOR. She occasionally sl and stutters through her rant.  74.
I have her upstairs in my room taking a pregnancy test cause apparently you’re so fucking incompetent that you let my daughter get fucked by some hick from town.
She’s pregnant? CELESTE throws her hands up.

Unless she’s as unlucky as me then probably not but I want her to feel the unease of waiting for the results to come in because a parent, or legal guardian, disciplines the kid, doesn’t just hang out with them.
I’m sorry. I had no idea.
You fucked up. CELESTE holds up two fingers.
Twice.
I know you’re mad but-
How could I be so stupid?! If you did so badly with me how could I ever expect you to do right by her. ELEANOR stammers...
I knew she was seeing a guy but it didn’t seem physical, I swear.
Are you a retard?
No.

(slowly) Ya know, Ellie, sometimes your jaw slacks in this certain way like your life is just happening to you and you just look like a retard. ELEANOR blinks, not sure how to respond. Tears stream dow her face.
Don’t say that about me.
Only crazy people get aggravated when you call them crazy so you must really be retarded.
After everything I’ve done for you, how can you hate me so much?
Is that the kind of garbage you've been filling her head with? She told me all the shit you’ve been putting on her shoulders. CELESTE uses two fingers to press the middle of ELEANOR’s skull.
You have that hapless look like dad. ELEANOR sits down in a chair and sobs. HOLD ON THIS...

I have a press conference then two hours of round tables but I swear to God, Ellie, if my daughter comes back to me with that cross-eyed Guido’s kitten litter or Hepatitis Z, I'll throw you off that balcony. ELEANOR wipes the tears from her face.
If you threaten me ever again, I'll tell everyone I write your songs. CELESTE chews her jaw.  76.
Today I’d say that’s a stock you don't want to buy into.
A team of make- and hairstylists reset CELESTE’s face. The STYLIST walks over with a new blouse for her to chang into...
Here you go, dear. That’s better. THE MANAGER hovers around her, checking her out.
you look amazing. keep it simple. you’re gonna do great. He squeezes her shoulders.
CELESTE is on-stage in front of a packed press room. Flashbulbs are blinding.

First I’d like to say that I have.. an outpour of love for victims of this tragedy and victims of violence all over the world and I am deeply saddened to be associated with such an obscene and unnecessary tragedy... It’s a weird time we live in, and I guess, no matter how much we try and ignore these things that are really happening around us, they always find a way to creep in.
Jennifer Durst, WYNN NY, why do you think they targeted you? Do you assume there’s a connection to Ridgewood?  77.

No idea. I pretty much know as much as you so far, and since nobody's coming out and saying “we did this” yet, I'd really prefer not to speculate too much - but if they did pick that “disguise” on purpose I guess it’s cause they don’t like that I’m a woman or that I’ma successful woman. Maybe they don’t like that I had a kid when I was a kid. Maybe they think I’m a floozy. But I guess some of you think that too. CELESTE shrugs and smiles.
The way I have chosen to live my life goes against some people’s views about things.
Are there any links between you and central Europe?
I mean, not really. Not that I know of. I’ve never played there so I really don’t know. MODERATOR chimes in.
Next question... There, at the back.
Sorry, I just have one more. Are you and the band still going forward with the show tonight?
There’s really not enough information yet for us to justify canceling and my dad always says, “never postpone joy,” so yeah, I'll play if they let me. CELESTE smiles and shrugs.  78.

Afternoon, Meredith Desh, Atlantic City, Greater NorthEast, do you have anything you wish to communicate to the perpetrators of today’s attack? There’s a LONG BEAT... Hold on CELESTE. Bulbs flash over and over again.
(especially nonchalant) Yeah, I’d like to tell them that when I was a little girl I used to believe in God too... The statement hangs in the air.

-and if they ever come to their senses and they'd like something new to believe in, they can start believing in me cause I’m the new faith and I’m not afraid of them. Hell, I’d even like to extend an invite to my show tonight. I’1l be sure to put “cowards in masks” on the guest list.
I’m sorry but can you clarify what you mean exactly?
JOSIE and THE MANAGER bury their faces in their hands as shoot up for further questioning.
I don’t know. I’m just making a quip.
CELESTE and her team are packed into an elevator.  79.
are you out of your fucking mind?
I don’t want to talk about it.
we coached you on what to say and you said... the opposite. why the fuck would you start spewing all that weird shit out of your mouth?
You give it a try sometime. I was nervous.
i’m pretty certain if i follow, and correct me if i’m wrong, you compared yourself to some sort of a demigod and invited a group of terrorists to your fucking concert tonight.
Don’t give them so much credit, anyway, it was a joke.
not exactly how I think our sponsors are going to see it. do you actually believe that weird shit you said up there?
They wanted a show, I gave ‘ema show. They arrive at their floor and step out.
Alright, this place is swarming with press. Can I kindly ask you both to keep your mouths shut until we are finished? CELESTE winks at JOSIE.
Fine by me. JOSIE says to THE MANAGER.  80.
Let me handle it. Go smoke a cigarette or something.
JOSIE enters with CELESTE and tells the group...
(tongue in cheek) hello everybody. CELESTE seems even more strung out than before. She sits down in front of four journalists and various recording devices set up in front of her chair.

You have ten minutes, and as we currently have no more information regarding what’s happening across the Atlantic right now, I’d kindly like to ask everyone to keep the questions to tonight’s performance and the new album now as much as possible. JOSIE turns and exits. One journalist leads the charge.
Well, on that note then, can you tell us what audiences can expect from the new album?
Sci-fi anthems. The concept with this one was to create an experience as relentless and addictive as possible. A second JOURNALIST joins in...
I know we’ve just been asked to not talk about today’s attack but I guess I can’t help but let it contextualize my next question.
Okay...  81. CELESTE bites her lip.

It just got me thinking, do you feel that there’s been a shift in the culture where nihilist radical groups like this are increasingly keen on being perceived as superstars themselves? CELESTE is suddenly lucid and precise in her language. The group

I mean, who cares? I was hesitant to even give a statement today because all these ultra-violent thugs want is to make headlines. If everyone paid them no attention, they'd cease to exist - and so would people like me. That’s the only link I see between them and superstars. looks a little baffled by her digression.
-but I couldn’t just ignore the casualties, ya know. Makes me sick. JOURNALIST 2 writes down her statement.
Thanks for your answer, appreciate your candidness.

From the public’s perspective, this has been an- The JOURNALIST chooses his words. JOURNALIST (CONT’D) -emotional few years for you, bizarre events today very much included. Can you shed light on the significance of these upcoming arena performances for you personally?
This is the culmination of my life’s work so far. You know, we worked on it for two years before bringing it to the public.  82.
Why two years?
Year before that I was under a lot of stress after my accident- CELESTE smiles a bashful grin.
-and it’s an expensive event to put on, and we also waited on all the best people to become available to help us make it happen. I wanted all my best dancers back.
So, you consider these events a resurgence since the accident and arrest for “causing serious injury by dangerous driving?” CELESTE blinks.
Injury, not serious injury. I never stopped making music so I don’t consider it a “resurgence.” I just wanted to channel all that anxiety and suffering into something tangible, something positive.
Can you shed any light on why the case was abruptly dropped- LONG BEAT.
I see what you’re doing.
You brought it up.
Don’t try and have me say “abruptly” anything. CELESTE laughs and lights a cigarette.
There are three classifications of gunshot wounds to the spine. (MORE )

I’m type three which is when the bullet is actually inside the intervertebral disc space. Now, type three injuries are subdivided into (A) spinal lesion not associated with perforation of abdominal viscera or (B) injury with perforation of abdominal organs. Thankfully, I’m type A., but it’s no secret to anybody that I take meds for my injury and that I never shoulda been behind the wheel of a car that night. CELESTE exhales and calls out for JOSIE.
Josie!
I didn’t mean to upset you.

People used to talk about me like I was a hero and then all the sudden, I was lower than trailer trash. That’s what this show’s about; a rebirth. JOSIE, THE PUBLICIST enters the room to stop the intervie
Time’s up.
Have you been at all in contact with the victim, Mr. Joel Hedlund? CELESTE furrows her brow, suspicious.
Okay, that’s enough.
I said I can’t talk about it.
I thought we were talking about it just now. JOSIE grabs CELESTE.  84.
Does it not seem like an insensitive time to be bringing this up? I’ve had it. You and I are through, Tommy. I’m sick of this kinda shit from you.
I'm doing my job, Josie.
This guy’s trying to kick me while I’m down.
Celeste, stop, this is over.
That’s not what I’m trying to do. I’m sorry you've misunderstood.
Why don’t you go and write about what happened to those innocent people today instead of trying to tear me down.

We follow JOSIE and CELESTE as they walk briskly down the hall towards the stairwell. They pass several journalists sitting in folding chairs who are patiently waiting their turn for 10 minutes with CELESTE.
I’m standing everything down until after the show. I want you to go to your room and get some rest. SOME REST, okay? I’m serious. I’1l come get you at 6.30. What floor are you on?
One floor up. 1823. INT. CELESTE’S SUITE - MOMENTS LATER
CELESTE enters to find THE MANAGER and ALBERTINE posed against her suite’s beachfront view in the middle of an embrace.  85.
Get your hands off her. THE MANAGER squints his brow and lifts his hands from ALBERTINE.
i came in here and she was crying by herself. she needed a hug. CELESTE speaks only to ALBERTINE.
Go downstairs and get ready for the show. ALBERTINE starts to rush past CELESTE but CELESTE catches her.
Come on, don’t do that. She whispers...
I hope you didn’t take that thing I gave you. I over-reacted. ALBERTINE doesn’t respond.
What? You want me to shout it from the rooftops? She pinches her daughter's side.
I’m just not ready for you to grow up is all. You’re my little girl. Forgive me? ALBERTINE sort of smiles and nods her head.

Hold on a minute. CELESTE grabs a bouquet of flowers from a vase in her roo and sets them next to some hotel stationary where she jot down a crudely written “I’m sorry I was a bitch” and sets it on a rose.
Give these to Ellie.  86. She shoves the bouquet at ALBERTINE.
What’s this for?
For everything. Take them down and I‘1l meet you guys in the lobby. We'll head over together. I love you.
Yeah, me too. ALBERTINE kisses her mom and exits...
why aren't you with Josie? CELESTE is almost startled.
Jesus. I almost forgot you were standing there. CAMERA pans over to THE MANAGER.
Josie called off the rest of the day. Some guy was coming after me about Joel Hedlund and I just didn’t have the mental capacity or balls to take him on.
christ. i'll go talk her off her a ledge.
No. Stay with me. CELESTE sits down with her legs spread across from THE MANAGER.
You got any stuff left from last night?
you think that’s a good idea right now?  87.
(frank, matter-of-fact) I’m done yammering for the day. THE MANAGER raises his eyebrows.

What? Tonight’s second nature. I gotta get out of my head, you know that. I’m getting myself all worked up from over-thinking everything. I keep picturing all those people screaming and running all over the sand. THE MANAGER exhales, unsure.

Come on, let’s just take what you have left. We won’t call for more until after the show and you can fuck me for a little while we’re high. CELESTE comically holds her hand up for a high five. THE MANAGER laughs, give her a high-five, then holds onto her hand. In a way, they really love each other.
THE MANAGER exits holding the door open for CELESTE who i some fancy new wardrobe but looks obliterated.
Come on, everyone’s downstairs. CELESTE trips out of the door, falls straight on her face THE MANAGER (CONT’D) (deadpan) You alright?
CELESTE seems almost dead in the backseat. ELEANOR, ALBERTINE, JOSIE, and THE MANAGER are all there, as well. Suddenly, CELESTE pops up to exclaim...
Stop the car!  88.
We’re running late.
Just pull over for 2 minutes.
What is it?
I just need to do something for 2 minutes. Stop the fucking car!
The van pulls over and CELESTE jumps out.
Honey, come with me for a sec.
ALBERTINE and CELESTE run up to the water and CELESTE kne down.
(to Albertine) Get down with me. ALBERTINE is concerned.
What are you doing
Let’s just have a moment of silence together. ALBERTINE cautiously kneels down.
Let’s shut our eyes and hold everyone who's suffering right now in our hearts. ALBERTINE shuts her eyes...
The water.  89.
A sign rotates advertising Celeste’s residence. The advertisement boasts- “CELESTE & THE DIRTY THIRTY PRESENTS VOX LUX: LIVE”

SFX: Constant percussion rises and falls in the mix. Occasionally blending with the pre-show recordings inside auditorium. A security team awaits CELESTE’S arrival. After some time van pulls up and CELESTE and her entourage exit the vehic JOSIE has to help CELESTE out of the sliding door.
A PA speaks up...
Can I help you Ms. Montgomery?
No one calls me that.
Give her some space. Are there cameras back there?
Not that I know of.
Tell your team if anyone is caught taking a picture of her, they’re fucking fired. JOSIE turns her attention to CELESTE JOSIE, THE PUBLICIST (CONT’D) What can we get you?
I'm so thirsty. JOSIE turns to the PA.  90.
Get her some sparkling water and something to eat.
Oh, sure, like what? JOSIE, ELEANOR, and THE MANAGER are nearly dragging her i the back entrance of the auditorium.
Something with sugar.
Where’s Albertine?
She's behind you.
Take her to get something to drink.
We're not leaving you. I’m right here. CELESTE looks behind her to see ALBERTINE.
There you are. Don’t look so upset. Just go and get something to drink and get your seat.
CELESTE’s LASER DIRECTOR greets her at the door.
I just needed to quickly introduce myself. I’m stepping in for O'Malley tonight. CELESTE looks at him but doesn’t respond.
Now’s not a great time. The LASER DIRECTOR suddenly sees what terrible shape she’ in.
Oh, sorry.  91. CELESTE’s eyes focus...
Who’s O’Malley?
Your laser director.
I’ve never met him. What happened to him?
He’s got a throat infection
-but this is the first show. JOSIE cuts him off..
I said now isn’t a good time! They keep walking. JOSIE looks across to THE MANAGER who yet to say a word. JOSIE, THE PUBLICIST (CONT’D) I need you to call this RIGHT NOW if she can’t go on.
she’s fine. (to Celeste) stop with the histrionics, baby. The PA walks ahead trying to make way for them.
There’s a room prepared just here on the left. The PA dictates a door on the left.
(shouts ) I KNOW! We’ve been here every day for a week. CELESTE shakes everyone loose.
Let go of me. She braces herself against the doorframe. They enter the room.  92.
Everyone thinks I’m an idiot.
No one thinks you’re an idiot.
(slurs) Just, shut up-
don't be a spoiled brat. you’re embarrassing yourself.
(shouts ) Don’t call me brat! ELEANOR says to JOSIE.
Get her out of here. Then to ALBERTINE. CELESTE shouts and rants behind her.
(belligerent shouting) I'm sick of everyone talking about me like I’m not a person! I’m not just a thing you can put on and wear!
Baby, your mom needs me right now and I need you to go with Josie. I’1l1 come out to you as soon as I can. Can you do that for me? I promise you everything is going to be all right, okay?
Okay.
Okay. ELEANOR shuts the door on the gang, leaving only CELESTE THE MANAGER with her in the room.

don’t feed into this unhealthy behavior, ellie. Then to Celeste, suddenly belligerent...  THE MANAGER (CONT’D) i’m sick and i’m tired of you treating us like we’re not a person. how about that? at least everyone is out there talking and worrying about you, spoiled brat. no one will ever drum up a thing to say about the rest of us, spoiled brat, and i don’t sit around whining about it.
You too. GET OUT OF HERE! CELESTE is an outright mess, sobbing and dazed.
seriously, she’ll be fine. she’s riding a bad wave that she’1l eventually come off of. we just need to snap some sense into her Then back to Celeste, he says...
you're in a hole, isn’t that right, cel? CELESTE has ceased to make much sense.
You can’t just press a button and take out your dishes!
okay, i think you’re really scaring everyone so you gotta just shut your eyes and pretend you’re the only one in the room. can you do that for me?
I said get out. THE MANAGER doesn’t budge.
Do you want me to call this off? He exhales, kisses CELESTE on the forehead and exits.

Everyone is talking about me like I’m not a person right in front of them! They’re right in front of me when they do it! ELEANOR holds CELESTE to her chest. CELESTE is an outrigh mess, sobbing and dazed.
He’s a car salesman. Forget about him.
Ellie, they showed me these promos we shot and I looked so bad.
What are you talking about?
No, don’t look at me like that, listen to me. They shot me with this new camera everyone told me is great but I looked so ugly. It made me want to die, Ellie. ELEANOR seems possessed.
You're not gonna die.
I just want to be queen for them and sometimes I don’t feel like a queen at all, ya know? I’m so ugly underneath all this and if they only knew- CELESTE cries with her eyes rolled back in her skull.
I’m so grateful you're alive and I'm here and I’m not going anywhere. Ever. CELESTE has her face buried in her sister’s neck.
But the journalists can be so mean, Ellie. They begin breathing in unison.  95.

That’s because they’ve never made anything they’re proud of, honey. You’re not here for them. You’re here for your fans. Tonight will be the greatest night of their lives and the public will be at your feet again. In just a few minutes, this nightmare you’ve been living will all be over, and it will have all been worth it... Let me help you get dressed.

We follow CELESTE, the PA, and a few others down a long corridor. She is now dressed in a surreal costume of whit feathers and structured shoulder pads that make her look a piece of Corbusier furniture. SFX: An ambient drone. Percussion continues to amass. The tension builds. They finally reach Celeste’s TOUR MANAGER and a few other who stand waiting for her.
Here she is.
You look amazing! CELESTE smiles, seems focused, less fucked up than before THE TOUR MANAGER (CONT’D) Are you ready?
My daughter’s out there. Gotta make this amazing for her.

Let’s get started. (calls out) Everyone gather round me and Cel, will ya? The band hold hands in a huddle. Her TOUR MANAGER leads a pre-show ritual.  96. THE TOUR MANAGER (CONT’D) I just want wanna say thank you for this beautiful group of talented people. I’d like to take a moment to reflect on the last year and this crew who are like family. None of this would be possible without you. Now, are you psyched for tonight?
Yeah!

Let’s give our girl some love! They start to chant and rap. CELESTE jumps around in the middle of the crew, she playf lunges at them like a prize-fighter. The group chants a melodic mantra, singing “phenomenal” o and over again. After a moment...
Who’s the badd-est bitch in the room! ?
You a-re!
Who’s the sickest b-and on the plan- et?
We a-re.
Who makes this possible?
We do!
Are we be gonna be good?!
No!
Are we gonna be great?! CELESTE is like a new person, completely in her element.  97.
Are we gonna be a-m-a-zing!?
What are we gonna be then?!
Phenomenal!

So, let us go higher and higher - and higher - and higher - and higher - and higher - and higher - and higher - and higher - and higher, break! She high fives the group breathes heavy, and steps to a platform where stylists put on a few finishing touches to hair and make up. Following the countdown from 10 Celeste is finally elevat to the stage on a lift. CAMERA stays tight on her on her rise up.

CELESTE stands in silhouette against a set of massive monitors that flash PAST, PRESENT, FUTURE over and over again behind her. The crowd of thousands is only occasionally illuminated i brief flashes of light. SFX: An ambient warble floods the space with sound. Percussion occasionally rises and falls in the mix. She speaks into a mic saturated with vocal fx.
(heavy reverb) TONIGHT. (MORE )

head_text.subj: WE ARE GONNA BRING IT BACK TO WHERE

text: IT ALL BEGAN (began, began, began). You want to travel back in time with me? The crowd cheers wildly.
I can’t hear YOU! The crowd cheers louder now.
That’s right, bitches... As some of you might have heard, Celeste is Latin for... “heavenly.” Do you find me heavenly? She suddenly strikes a new pose. Excessive cheering...
Ha ha, I hear all you angels. 70,000 of my little angels. She breathes heavy. The crowd A wave of
So, tell me, how many of you out there have ever had a boy break your heart (heart, heart, heart)? responds more and more to the playful tease.

That’s what I thought - and how many of my little angels cry themselves to sleep at night because somebody called you an ugly name? Fat, hideous, slut. Well, guess what? People have been trying to take me down for years but I won’t STAY DOWN. applause.

Listen close cause tonight is for you, angels. I hear your prayers. This is the new New Testament and tonight is ALL FOR YOU (you, you, you, you, you). A screen displaying a close-up of CELESTE’S face lights u behind her.  99. The monitors on the right and left flash VOICE, OF, LIGHT over and over again.
(no reverb) Welcome to the VOX LUX tour, a night you're not soon to forget.

head_text.subj: EXALT ME ALL THE WAY UP PAST THE

text: THE BEAT DROPS and light shoots up in wide beams all arou Celeste. A new shift in the light reveals a backdrop of massive wh squares, something unusually architectural like graph pap Then suddenly 60 DANCERS DRESSED EXACTLY AS CELESTE enter from the right and left and she is lost in the crowd of t They occasionally strike unique poses.
(sings in autotune)
RADIANT FLUX, FUTURE, CAN’T, COME
CELESTE breaks into a regular singing voice, suddenly alo on stage.

(sings) Reading the papers making up stories (stories) I got 50 to life but who’s on the jury (jury) Ya never met me but you already know me (know me) The same old shit, the same old story (story) CELESTE shifts her vocal style for the bridge...
I’m made of stone, not bone Made up of steel, nothing re-al. But I’m looking at you looking at me And I can feel my heart begin to take a be-at BACK to the CHORUS.  100.

head_text.subj: EVERYONE SINGS ALONG TO THE LYRICS.

text: The dancers return to the stage and lift CELESTE high abo them. SFX: Berlioz’s choral piece “La Damnation de Faust” start drown out all diegetic audio.
- Drummer, triumphant - Keyboards, triumphant - Violins, triumphant - THE MANAGER watches from the wings, triumphant
CELESTE’s face being carried and passed over by the dance underneath her. HOLD ON THIS... HOLD.

Late one night at the hospital, following that fateful morning at Ridgewood, Celeste made a maddening claim that only her sister had ever sensed to be true. She recounted a story to Eleanor that went like this... Shortly after her classmate pulled the trigger and sent her to the place between life and death, a Place that she could only really ever describe to Eleanor as a “rush of color;” she had met the devil and made a deal with him in exchange for her life. He whispered her melodies and she returned with a mission to bring great change to the next century. BEAT.  101. NARRATOR (CONT’D) He said, “shut your eyes and repeat after me.” CELESTE begins to shut her eyes... The NARRATOR speaks now at a very deliberate pace. NARRATOR (CONT’D) One for the money. Two for the show. On three we get ready. And on four - come with me. CELESTE’s expression conveys that though her spirit is exhausted at the peak of its achievement, it really has a been an achievement, nonetheless.
ALBERTINE watches her mother from the from the front row. CUT TO BLACK. LOU REED’s “SWORD OF DAMOCLES” PLAYS LOUD, REDEMPTIVE,
